aloe.logic_concept module

class aloe.logic_concept.ArithmeticComparison(arg1, arg2, symbol)

Bases: Comparison

evaluate(subst)
class aloe.logic_concept.ArithmeticExpression

Bases: LogicConcept, ABC

abstract apply(fun)

Applies the function fun() to all sub-LogicConcepts if any.

sub-LogicConcepts are any LogicConcept object present as attributes of another LogicConcept Ex:

  • Clauses have Atoms as sub-LogicConcepts

  • Predicates have Terms as sub-LogicConcepts

  • Variables have no sub-LogicConcepts

Parameters:

  • fun (function): the function to apply.

Returns:

  • None or a new LogicConcept on which :param:`fun` has been applied.

abstract evaluate(subst)

class aloe.logic_concept.Variable(symbol, tally_id=0)

Bases: Term

This class represents variables in the first order logic framework Variable objects are distinguished by - a symbol: a string (Ex: ‘A’, ‘Father’) - a tally id: a integer There can be several Variable objects with the same symbol. To distinguish among them, we use a tally id. A negative tally id means that the Variable object doesn’t belong to a tally

apply(fun)

Applies the function fun() to all sub-LogicConcepts if any.

sub-LogicConcepts are any LogicConcept object present as attributes of another LogicConcept Ex:

  • Variables have no sub-LogicConcepts

property symmetric_difference
property symmetric_difference_update
property union
update([E, ]**F) → None.  Update D from dict/iterable E and F.

If E is present and has a .keys() method, then does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E is present and lacks a .keys() method, then does: for k, v in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k in F: D[k] = F[k]

class aloe.learner.ProgolLearner(**options)

Bases: Learner

Inductive logic learner as described by S. Muggleton in ‘Inverse entailment and progol.’ 1995 available at http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.31.1630&rep=rep1&type=pdf

build_bottom_i(e, M, B, solver)

For better understanding, read this function along Fig.1. ‘Algorithm for constructing bottom’ in page 14 of document tutorial4.4.pdf Inputs: - e: a single example (Clause object) - M: the set of all modes (ModeCollection object) - B: the background knowledge (Knowledge object) - solver: the engine to verify expressions (Solver object)

Ouput: Object from aloe.clause

Parse string <string> containing multiple times the rule <rule>

split_on_dots(text)
class aloe.parser.AloeVisitor

Bases: NodeVisitor

`tree = grammar.parse(text)´ parses the string ‘text’ in the form of a tree.

-> This class allows to navigate the tree obtained.

`AloeVisitor().visit(tree)´

– navigates through the parsed tree – transforms it into a Clause object

def visit_x(self, node, visited_children):

– with x, a non-terminal symbol – corresponds to a production rule: x -> … Inputs:

– visited_children is the list of returned values from each child
Ex: headlessclause = “:-” body “.”
visited_children = [[], val_body, []]

– children of “:-” and “.” are [] – val_body is the value returned by body

Special children:

– `x?´ -> [] or [child_x] – `x*´ -> [child_x1, …, child_xn] – `(x y)´ -> [child_x, child_y] – x / y -> [child_x] or [child_y]

– node: the current node from the parsed tree

Output:

– The transformation for symbol x, given the inputs

generic_visit(node, visited_children)

The default visit method.

aloe.substitution module

class aloe.substitution.Substitution

Bases: object

This class represents a substitution of variables It has three properties: - variables: the domain of substitution, a set of Variable objects - tally: dict giving for a symbol the number of Variable objects with the symbol - subst: dict mapping a Variable object to a term

add_variable(variable)

Adds a single variable to the domain of the substitution

add_variables(expr)

Adds all variables present in expr to the domain of the substitution

copy()
static from_mode(M)
static generic_name_for_variables(expr)
get_type_subst(atom, M, body_atom=False)
items()

Creates a new variable with symbol=symbol

remove_excess_variables(domain)

Keep only variables in domain

rename_variables(x, subst=None, new_variables=True)
substitute(expr)

Apply substitution to expression <expr>

unify(atom1, atom2)

Tries to match two atoms together and iteratively updates self.subst If not possible, raises a SubstitutionError

update()
